ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
IMPOUNDING OF PASSPORTS


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will inform the House of the provisions of the law under which the Immigration Department and other Government departments are empowered to impound valid passports of citizens.

     Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, Question 1. But before that is answered, may I say, before any accusation is made, that I have no pecuniary interest in this question. I have, of course, written on behalf of a person, need I say who, to ask under what powers her passport was impounded. But I have no pecuniary interest at all.

     The Minister of State for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Law): Sir, the Passports Regulation 15(1)(a), read with section 3(1)(g) of the Passports Act, empowers the Controller of Immigration to cancel a Singapore passport. The passport would be impounded after cancellation.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I know under what conditions the Singapore passport may be cancelled? Are there any conditions set out?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, under regulation 15(1)(a), the Minister for Home Affairs can give instructions to the Controller of Immigration to cancel the passport. He exercises his discretion in matters where public law and order is concerned. He can issue this instruction.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I know for what reasons or conditions that the restricted passport of Mrs Tang was impounded by the Immigration Department?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) had informed the Minister for Home Affairs that they were investigating the tax matters of Mr Tang Liang Hong, and that Mrs Tang Liang Hong (Madam Teo Siew Har) was involved in removing some tax files from Mr Tang's office to the home. And that she also may be of assistance in

Column: 331

answering questions on the administration of Mr Tang's tax matters. The Comptroller of Income Tax was of the view that her passport should be cancelled and impounded. The Minister for Home Affairs considered these grounds and, considering them to be valid, exercised his powers under regulation 15.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I ask whether the Minister is aware that under section 87 of the Income Tax Act the power is given to the Comptroller of Income Tax to direct that any person leaving Singapore should be stopped or prevented if he has not paid taxes assessed upon him? Is it under this section that the decision was taken or was it under any other section?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, obviously, Mr Jeyaretnam has not listened to my answer carefully. I stated that it was under the Passports Act and the Passports Regulations wherein the powers have been exercised, not the Income Tax Act.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I understood the Minister to say that it was because some files were removed from Mr Tang's office by the income tax officer that it was deemed necessary to prevent Mrs Tang leaving. Was it because of that or not?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, again, the Member has not listened to my answer carefully. She was involved herself in the removal of some files from Mr Tang's office. And as IRAS was investigating his tax matters, the Comptroller was of the view that she would be of assistance in answering and furnishing information to the Comptroller on Mr Tang's tax matters.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister say whether any taxes were due from Mrs Tang at the time that her passport was impounded?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, that was not the issue. That was not the purpose for impounding her passport. IRAS was very carefully investigating a person's tax matters, in this case, Mr Tang Liang Hong. They have to do their job judiciously and thoroughly. And if a person is deemed to

Column: 332

be able to assist in these investigations, and in this case it is not just that, but she was seen to be involved in removing some of the files from Mr Tang's office, the Comptroller in carrying out his duties would want to be thorough and therefore made a request to the Minister for Home Affairs to cancel and impound her passport, so that she can help in the investigations.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Will the Minister then confirm that it did not come under section 87 at all?

    Assoc Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I have said it before, no.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Thank you. I have no supplementary question, Sir. But may I raise with you, for further clarification, the reasons advanced on your behalf for disallowing my other Question to the Prime Minister that was submitted, asking why Parliament could not sit in March.

     Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Jeyaretnam, your question has not been admitted on grounds which were, in fact, conveyed to you. The inadmissibility of a Question for Oral Answer is not a ground for debate in this House. I believe the reasons for disallowing your Question have been communicated to you and you should let the matter rest at that.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the grounds that were advanced were that it had been dealt with.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, as I pointed out to you, inadmissibility of a Question cannot be the subject of a debate in the Chamber. That is provided for under the Standing Orders.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: If it pleases you, Sir.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Fourth Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [2nd June, 1997],

    `That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

Column: 333



    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".'. - [Dr Wang Kai Yuen]

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I caught your eye, and I will not exhaust the 30 minutes that have been allocated to me. I would be short.

    Sir, I would like to bring up two major issues which are critical to Singapore's long-term social and economic stability. These two issues need to be pondered carefully and we need to manage them effectively. First, we must pay particular attention to the lurking danger in the resurgence of fanatical groups and individuals within and outside Singapore. We cannot take Singapore's racial, religious and language harmony for granted.

    Sir, as you know, many countries which have long progressive developments are now plagued by various types of fanatics. The first type, as you are aware of, is the religious fanatics who push for one religion over all others. The second type is the racial fanatics who demand for the dominance of one race over all others. The third type is the language fanatics who assert the supremacy of one language over others. Sir, you can see what has happened to countries such as Lebanon, Bosnia, Sri Lanka, Fiji, Cyprus and Northern Ireland. Many of these countries have long histories and today they are all broken. They are plagued by conflicts, issues and problems between people of various persuasions. They were thriving economies and culturally vibrant places, but if we examine and assess them they have become fractured by racial, religious and language conflicts.

    Sir, young Singaporeans must learn from the sad lessons of these places and take steps to ensure that various types of fanatics are deterred to take root in Singapore. And history is obviously a good lesson and by examining the various episodes and problems faced by these countries, they are very important lessons that we all need to draw, appreciate and understand, so that in Singapore we can take pre-emptive steps to deal with these critical and crucial issues.

Column: 334



    Sir, our social institutions providing education, housing and employment must take proactive steps to enable our young to respect and appreciate one another, irrespective of their language, race or religion. We must continue to actively immunise our younger generations to socially integrate through economic, educational and community activities. In short, we have to socialise our young to think, feel and be Singaporeans. I say it is not just sufficient for Singaporeans to feel and to think, but to behave and to act as Singaporeans. I feel that this is most critical and most important.

    I am sure that all our social institutions will strive to achieve this objective by taking various conscious steps and different ways to encourage more multi-racial participation of people in various social and economic activities. I am of the opinion that it must be a conscious effort whether we like it or not because Singapore is a multi-racial society. We have peoples of various persuasions and this must remain an important and crucial thing within the backdrop of our minds.

    Sir, we can further strengthen our bonds among our ethnic groups. The first place to start with is in the pre-schools in our neighbourhoods where effective integration and steps need to be taken, so that the very young, having to socialise with various ethnic groups, can participate in various activities which can help us build stronger bonds.

    On a more serious note, my grave concern is on the potential danger of the rise of fanatical individuals and groups outside Singapore who can do harm to Singapore and Singaporeans. Worse still from a fanatical leader that we may have no control. In the face of this potential threat, Singaporeans must be alert and be street-wise to band together to deal with such problems which can arise. We live in an uncertain world, and anything can hit us at any time, but we must be prepared to deal with it graciously. And this I am sure Singaporeans will be able to respond. We hope that there will continue to be rational and cooperative leaders in the region who will work for the common good of all peoples in ASEAN and other

Column: 335

regions. It is through this common bond of brotherhood in international relations, mutual support and understanding that we can build a better regional community, a better world.

    Sir, I feel that Singaporeans and Malaysians all want to live and work as best friends and we have over the years cultivated very good relationship and we all want to maintain this positive relationship.

    We have good people-to-people relationship over the years and I hope that we can continue to build on this and strengthen better mutual understanding and support of one another.

    Sir, the second issue that we need to pay closer attention, I must say, is to enable the less better off to improve their stations in life. In our strive for material pursuits, we must not forget that we have social obligations to help those who are less better off and less socially endowed. In a social and economic marathon, there will always be people who are going to do less better and we want to ensure that they participate in the race and we should find ways to enable these people to achieve and to be in the race. We cannot afford to ignore them. To do so would make our society cold and uncaring. I look forward for more governmental contributions and together with community and voluntary efforts and corporate support, we can do more and help the less privileged and the less endowed. More Edusave scholarships and bursaries could be given to a larger number of families. I think the criteria need to be reviewed so that families that are outside the boundary can be included for help and education can be an inroad to assist them to achieve better lives.

    Sir, for the common man, basic services such as health care, housing, education and transportation should remain affordable. As you are aware, more public services are to be restructured or corporatised. It is necessary for the Government to set up a body to monitor and check the charges so that we can ensure that the

Column: 336

prices that are charged by these institutions are fair and accessible for the common man.

    Sir, in conclusion, to make Singapore more versatile, we must work together as a team and promote the best of relationship with Malaysians and other peoples of ASEAN.

     Dr Teo Ho Pin (Sembawang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion moved by the Member for Bukit Timah in expressing our thanks to the President for his Address at the opening of the Ninth Parliament.

    The President has given a very comprehensive speech anchored on five pillars which will usher Singapore into the 21st century. These five pillars: create wealth, share success, invest in the young, look after the old, and build ties will be the guiding principles for all Singaporeans to work together for a better future.

    As we move into the next millennium, Singapore will face two main challenges: intense competition and rising expectations of people. With greater liberalisation of trade and open economy, competition will be more intense both locally and in the global market. The rising expectations of people will also pose immense challenges to Singapore to improve our performance and provide better quality services.

    To cope with these challenges, we need to focus on improving the quality of our environment, services, products and, at the same time, increase the productivity of our workforce. Quality and productivity must be the main thrust to make Singapore a world-class city.

    I am very pleased to note that the President has emphasised the need to upgrade the physical environment and build Singapore into a city of excellence. In line with the President's call, I would like to focus on "How to develop Singapore into a world-class city". I will highlight three areas of concern: (1) Planning, (2) Design, and (3) Construction.

Column: 337



    Sir, I will first discuss on the area of planning. We must adopt an integrated planning approach to make Singapore a world-class city.

    First of all, integrated planning. Singapore has gained a world reputation for its forward and far-sighted planning of the city. Over the last 32 years, we have developed excellent infrastructure, buildings and amenities to make Singapore a city for business, living and recreation. The recent Development Guide Plans have also incorporated a variety of urban forms to make Singapore a vibrant and interesting city to work and live in.

    The creation of the New Downtown at Marina South is an example of how integrated planning can help to provide Singaporeans with a vibrant and exciting environment.

    I understand that the relevant authorities have been working closely to ensure that the plans meet the country's needs at the strategic level. I hope that more coordination and cooperation could be achieved at the operational level as well to facilitate developments in both the public and private sectors.

    With the advent of information technology, more planning information can be made known to developers, consultants and contractors to avoid unnecessary delays in development and wastage of resources in abortive or corrective works. We should consider developing web sites for all Development Guide Plans so that all developments could be instantly updated. This would help developers, consultants and contractors to plan their projects more effectively and efficiently.

    Secondly, our planners. Credit must be given to our planners who had taken bold initiative to develop Singapore into a city of excellence over the last 32 years. In the face of growing competition, our planners must strive to make Singapore a more attractive place for business and investment. We should continue to attract and retain good planners so that plans could be implemented and fine-tuned to make Singapore a world-class city.

    Sir, I will now move on to the second area: Design. We must encourage more

Column: 338

innovative and creative designs for our built environment. First of all, innovate design. More creative and innovative designs are needed so as to meet the rising expectations and aspirations of the people. In the next century, we will have more elderly people, and users will be more knowledgeable and demanding.

    More user friendly, functional and maintainable designs must be adopted so as to achieve more comfort, higher productivity and better quality of life. In addition, buildings must be designed to be easily accessible and well-integrated with the transportation system and other amenities to meet the users' needs.

    Secondly, private sector participation in HDB housing. The private sector should be further encouraged to participate in our public housing programmes to provide more variety and options to Singaporeans. At present, about 10-15% of HDB new flats are built using the design-and-build or design-plus methods whereby private architects are involved.

    With more private sector involvement, more new ideas can be introduced to make HDB living more interesting and pleasant. However, HDB should continue to conduct quality audit so as to ensure that designs of HDB flats remain buildable, functional, practical and maintainable.

    The combination of expertise from both the HDB and private sector will produce a new breed of public housing that will better meet the housing aspirations of Singaporeans in the 21st century.

    Thirdly, designs for enhancing community bonding. The HDB precinct concept should be further expanded so that communal spaces are specifically designed to promote social cohesion and community bonding of the people. We should adopt the condominium concept whereby social centre or communal space is created for residents to interact and develop bonding.

    Eventually, more autonomy should be accorded to residents to take responsibility in maintaining their living environment. This joint responsibility will further strengthen the bond of the people, thus leading to a stronger community.

Column: 339



    Fourthly, HDB upgrading programmes. The HDB upgrading programme has been a great success. Many Singaporeans have gained or are aware of the immense benefits of the programme. The Estate Renewal Strategy, Main and Interim Upgrading Programmes have successfully rejuvenated older estates and enchanced the quality of life of many residents.

    A recent survey was conducted by the NUS School of Building and Real Estate to determine the impact of the Main Upgrading Programme on the quality of life of residents. The majority of residents surveyed (more than 70% of them) from eight upgraded precincts felt that upgrading has improved the quality of their lives.

    Certain design features were specifically highlighted as having enhanced their quality of living. These included lifts at every floor, covered walkways, new lift interior and landscaped gardens. I hope the Government could consider giving an additional grant to incorporate these design features as standard items in future upgrading programmes.

    Sir, I will now move on to the third area of concern: Construction. We must upgrade the construction industry. First of all, build a quality construction workforce. In order to develop Singapore into a world-class city, we need to upgrade the capability of our construction industry. The construction industry plays a significant role in contributing to the GDP of Singapore. In 1996, it contributed 8.5% to the National Economy. Despite this, the industry is plagued with problems of low productivity and labour shortages.

    These shortcomings have adversely affected the quality of construction services and inhibited regionalisation efforts of the industry. We need to build a quality construction workforce comprising multi-skilled tradesmen, supervisory and professional staff in Singapore. The construction industry encounters much difficulty in attracting Singaporeans to work in the industry. This is attributed to the tough and dangerous working conditions at construction sites.

Column: 340



    Many young Singaporeans shun the industry, thus leaving many construction firms with no choice but to rely on foreign workers. This situation is not desirable and construction firms are unable to maintain a stable pool of skilled construction personnel.

    I hope the Government could provide more support to improve the image of the industry and encourage more Singaporeans to pursue a career in the construction industry.

    More incentives such as tax rebates could be given to construction firms which employ Singaporeans. Incentives should be provided to encourage staff to stay with the same employers for a number of years. This will help firms to maintain a stable workforce, thus improving their productivity and quality of work.

    Secondly, maintaining construction workload. To maintain a stable workforce, construction firms must procure adequate contracts. The fluctuating workload of construction firms is one factor which has prevented firms from employing more direct staff. More support and encouragement such as tender premiums should be given to firms with good track record and direct workforce. If possible, more design and build or negotiation contracts from the public sector could be awarded to these firms. In Japan, many of the large construction firms are able to maintain a large pool of direct workers (between 10,000 and 15,000 staff) due to their ability to obtain work through design and build and negotiation procurement methods. These contractual arrangements have enabled Japanese firms to achieve higher productivity and quality of work, thus winning their clients' confidence for future contracts.

    Thirdly, safe working environment. We need to provide a safe and conducive working environment at construction sites. Statistics from the Labour Ministry revealed that the construction industry has the highest number of fatal accidents (43 cases) in 1995 as compared to other industries. These figures clearly show that more must be done to develop a safety culture in the construction industry.

Column: 341



    The provision of a safe and conducive working environment should be the joint responsibility of the authorities, developers, consultants and contractors. I am glad to know that steps have been taken to set aside certain sums of money in accordance with the size of the contract to ensure that proper safety measures are taken and housekeeping is carried out to make our construction sites safe and tidy.

    The Labour Ministry has been conducting safety training courses to address this problem. To succeed, we need the collective efforts of all parties involved in a construction project.

    Fourthly, help construction firms to grow. To date, we have a total of 121 G8 construction firms registered in general building, civil engineering and piling works. These firms can undertake projects of unlimited contract value. However, not many of them have annual turnover of more than $100 million. In 1996, only $1.5 billion out of $16 billion value of contracts in the construction industry was from overseas market. This accounts for a mere 10% of construction services being exported to other countries. Many of our local construction firms are family based businesses which have limited resources to grow into big construction firms of international standing. Despite much encouragement, the growth of construction firms is slow.

    I hope the Government will initiate the pooling of resources in the construction industry. Firms with high growth potentials should be given more financial incentives to upgrade and expand their operations. Incentives must be given to encourage partnership between construction firms, development firms and financial institutions to undertake overseas projects. To be able to seize the immense opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region, we must build a core group of contractors which have the financial capability and construction expertise to compete in the global market.

    Fifthly, buildable designs and precast technology. I am pleased to note that the National Development Minister has recently re-emphasised and encouraged

Column: 342

architects to use more simple-to-build designs and precast technology. These measures have proved to be very successful in Europe and Japan in increasing productivity and quality. In Singapore, HDB has achieved excellent results in adopting buildable designs and precast technology. There is an urgent need to spearhead the use of these techniques in our industry.

    Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, to develop Singapore into a World-class City is a daunting task. We have the will, expertise and resources to achieve this goal. But, we need to focus on the three areas which I have mentioned: Planning, Design and Construction. With the support of a good Government, both the public and private sectors will be able to make Singapore a better home for all of us.

     Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed (Cheng San): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for the opportunity to speak at this session. I rise in support of the motion by the hon. Member for Bukit Timah.

    Sir, to my mind, the gist of the President's Address highlights the need for us to stand tall, to stand proud of and to stand up for Singapore. However, these are also areas where if we are not careful, we can be misinterpreted as being conceited, arrogant and insensitive. No, I am not saying that we should offer our other cheek, but instead let us put our shoulders to the wheel and stand together, graciously.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, before I proceed on this point, allow me first to share with the House some of my thoughts about Parliament and I.

    When I first took my seat here last week, I must confess that I felt not a little over-awed by the imposing stateliness and the dignity of the House, and the presence of some of the strongest pillars, some of the most important people in the history of modern Singapore and its success.

    Almost before that feeling passed, I was struck by the realisation that I was now a member of this body charged with looking after and securing the future of our country and our people.

Column: 343



    Together with the privilege of service comes the responsibility - no, the obligation - to give of our best to justify the people's trust in us.

    As elected MPs, it is our sacred duty to strive to satisfy as many as possible the people's wants and needs - social, economic and political. To help them meet and overcome their problems, to examine and explore their views and ideas, and to help them achieve their aspirations and goals. In the multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-cultural dynamics of Singapore, these are perforce, diverse and ever-changing and not always easy to handle. But we must try anyway.

    We are the voice of the people and a vital link between them and the Government. If we do not speak up for them, who would. Though, of course, we must always be careful of the many different sensitivities at play.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in this House, I intend to speak my mind, though I shall also mind what I say. Honestly and sincerely, no man can do more, and the people of Singapore deserve no less. We must not run away from our responsibilities just because issues raised or policies adopted may be unpleasant or unpopular.

    We are Singaporeans, pragmatic and realistic. Our leaders have brought us thus far, that we can walk with our heads held high in any company, not by sweeping the dust under the carpet but facing adversity down and turning obstacles into opportunities.

    Against all odds, Singapore has not only survived but also succeeded beyond expectations. We are eternally grateful to the early leaders for all they have done, for all their personal sacrifices. But we cannot afford to rest on our laurels. If conditions were difficult in the early years, they promise to be even tougher in the future.

    Domestically, the people have higher expectations and demands. Ironically, this has come about because of the country's success. With the attendant higher

Column: 344

    This Government is a cross-century government, because it will lead Singapore from the 20th century into the 21st century. Different ages and different times face different questions, problems and challenges. Every country, at different stages of development and different times in history, also has to face different kinds of problems and challenges. As such, the key to survival is to be able to overcome all the problems and meet all the challenges. In the ever-turning wheel of history, we have seen countless ups and downs, successes and failures.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in order to face the future challenges, as a citizen, I think there are two things we have to bear in mind. Firstly, it is to learn from the past for the sense of crisis which would motivate us to struggle for our survival. Secondly, we must make every effort to enhance our awareness for competitiveness.

    At the time of separation from Malaysia, we were really desperate and everybody thought we had no chance of survival. But we made it. We actually found a way out against all odds. I think in this context, the sense of crisis played a very important role. That generation of Singaporeans all had a very strong sense of crisis or "crisis consciousness". Since separation from Malaysia, we worked very hard for more than 30 years. Today, with all the success and prosperity, Singaporeans seem to have lost their sense of crisis. Long periods of stability and development have brought to our people security and confidence. Is it good or bad? I think it can be both. Good in the sense that we have confidence and the courage to face our future positively. Bad in the sense that some of our people have become complacent and arrogant.

    It is generally known in military strategy that, "An army burning with righteous indignation is bound to win, and an army puffed up with pride is bound to lose." This is precisely the reason why the hare lost its race against the slow-moving tortoise, in the famous fable.

    In the 60s and 70s, we were an army of righteous indignation. We had no other options. We had to bei shui yi zhan

Column: 354

( : fight with one's back to the river) that is, fight to win or die, and pofu chenzhou ( : break the cauldrons and sink the boats after crossing) that is, cut off all means of retreat and be absolutely resolute to win or die. Now, what we must do is to prevent our people from an army which is puffed with pride, or like the conceited hare in the fable. Otherwise, we may end up "surviving the turbulent times yet succumbing in times of peace and happiness".

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not possible for us to recreate artificially the sense of crisis to stimulate the fighting spirit of our citizens, because the sense of crisis is a product of circumstances. So, I think what we should do is to try and enhance the competitive awareness among our people.

However, I notice also that the competitive awareness of some of our people is either not correctly oriented or simply inadequate. For example, some people may ask: why should we want to be No. 1 in every field? Why must Singapore be fighting to be the first in everything? Some people say that Singapore is very small, competition is very intense and the pressure is getting more and more heavy all the time. I think this sort of thinking exists because these people have inadequate competitive awareness or they have failed to understand the real meaning of competitive awareness. They should understand that apart from internal competition, the greater competition actually comes from outside, or the external environment for survival. Some people do not fully understand that keeping our advantage or edge in the competition is our means for survival. That is why I believe that competitive awareness is one key component we must include in our proposed National Education.

Column: 355

object lesson, we can tell the rise and fall of a nation." We must always be prepared for danger in times of peace.     We all know that Taiwan is one of the four little dragons of Asia. Taiwan's development started earlier than Singapore, and at a faster pace too. In my opinion, the experiences of Taiwan provides us with a lot of lessons to learn from.

On television, we can see thousands and thousands of demonstrators taking to the streets, calling on the government to resign, because they could not solve all these crimes. The Taiwanese experience tells us that to move from order to disorder is easy, but to restore law and order from chaos is very difficult. It is just like a jigsaw puzzle. You need to spend a lot of time to put all the pieces together. But if you want to break them, it is just so easy. You can do instantaneously. In English, they use the expression: "to open up the Pandora's box". The consequences are unthinkable. It is beyond control. Once social order is in jeopardy, it will affect not only the confidence of the people, but the confidence of the investors as well. This will be detrimental to the competitiveness of a country. Now the Taiwanese are saying that they should resort to heavy punishment to deal with the social disorder. But we know that when politics and the underworld are tied up together, as in the case of Taiwan, to move from disorder to order is not easy. Here, I would like to refer to one article in the New News Weekly which says: " The ill fate of Taiwan is like a heavy object dropping into the water. It sinks deeper and deeper. into a cruel society. 1996 was the watershed. The number of serious crimes of violence suddenly jumped from 917 cases to more than 1,400 cases. We should never allow the underworld the opportunity to raise its ugly head again to jeopardize our social security. Column: 358

Singaporeans. In other words, they are giving the warning to us that our survival is in their hands. So long as they cut our water supply, we cannot live anymore.
